ygData.msgSnippet: ... would ... layer. ... each ... hidden ... input ... Note that there is a difference between a weight being set to zero and the connection not even existing.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "bmiller3230" <bmiller3230@h...> wrote:
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Philip Tucker <ptucker@g...> wrote:
> > > > If, by input connections, you mean connections
> > > > incoming to the input
> > > > layer,  those don't have weights, they serve only to
> > > > pass the input
> > > > values to the input neurons.
> > > <snip>
> > > 
> > > Whoa!  In my experience most ANNs have weights here,
> > > lots of them.  It's often the case that the majority
> > > of the weights are between the inputs and the first
> > > layer of neurons.
> > 
> > I think we're dealing with ambiguous terminology here.  The first
> > layer of neurons in ANJI are responsible for nothing more than 
> passing
> > the input data on to the rest of the network.  They do have an
> > activation function, but typically this is just linear (i.e., it
> > effectively does not have an activation function).
> > 
> > So, if you do not view these neurons as a layer, then what I 
would
> > call the first hidden layer is what you would call the input 
layer. 
> > And yes, the inputs to this layer do have weights.
> > 
> > ANJI does allow the first layer of neurons to be connected to 
each
> > other if recurrency is enabled.  And, in NEAT there really is no
> > concept of layers, just neurons and connections.
> > 
> > - Philip
> 
> 
> Right--what we're trying to accomplish here is starting with a 
> minimalst network.  FS-NEAT suggests not only starting wih the 
hidden 
> topology being evolved, but the input layer as well--with the 
input 
> weights all set to zero, I'm hoping the inputs will be evolved as 
> well.
> 

Note that there is a difference between a weight being set to zero 
and the connection not even existing.  FS-NEAT starts with most 
connections literally not there at all.  That is a lot stricter than 
starting with weights of zero because a connection has to exist 
before it can be peturbed, making the likelihood of any given 
connection suddenly "coming into existence" much lower.

ken
